natural problem: Every June 1, an ecologist takes a census of the number of wrens in a state park. She noticed that the number is decreasing by $40\%$ each year. If this trend continues, in what year will the census show that the number of wrens is less than $10\%$ of what it was on June 1, 2004?
natural solution: After one year, there will be $60\%$ left. After two years, there will be $36\%$ left. After three years, there will be $21.6\%$ left. As we can see, these are just increasing powers of $60\%$, the next year will not dip below $10\%$, because $60\% > 50\%$, and $21.6 > 20$.

However, without calculating it exactly, you know that it will be less than $16.6\%$, and thus, it will take 5 years - meaning that in $\boxed{2009}$, the total number of wrens will drop below $10\%$ of what it originally was.

a_0.formal problem:
theorem
fixes wrens :: "int \<Rightarrow> int"
assumes h0 : "wrens 2004 > 0"
and h1 : "\<forall> n. n \<ge> 2004 \<longrightarrow> wrens (n + 1) = wrens n - (2 * wrens n div 5)"
and h2 : "\<exists> n. n \<ge> 2004 \<and> wrens n < (wrens 2004 div 10)"
shows  "n = 2009"
a_0.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 Every June 1, an ecologist takes a census of the number of wrens in a state park. She noticed that the number is decreasing by $40\%$ each year. If this trend continues, in what year will the census show that the number of wrens is less than $10\%$ of what it was on June 1, 2004? The final Answer is 2009
 ### Proof
 After one year, there will be $60\%$ left. After two years, there will be $36\%$ left. After three years, there will be $21.6\%$ left. As we can see, these are just increasing powers of $60\%$, the next year will not dip below $10\%$, because $60\% > 50\%$, and $21.6 > 20$.
 However, without calculating it exactly, you know that it will be less than $16.6\%$, and thus, it will take 5 years - meaning that in $\boxed{2009}$, the total number of wrens will drop below $10\%$ of what it originally was.
 *)

theorem
fixes wrens :: "int \<Rightarrow> int"
assumes h0 : "wrens 2004 > 0"
and h1 : "\<forall> n. n \<ge> 2004 \<longrightarrow> wrens (n + 1) = wrens n - (2 * wrens n div 5)"
and h2 : "\<exists> n. n \<ge> 2004 \<and> wrens n < (wrens 2004 div 10)"
shows  "n = 2009"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_0.informal problem: The population of wrens in a certain area was positive in the year 2004. Each year after 2004, the population of wrens decreases by two-fifths of the population of the previous year. There is a year after 2004 such that the population of wrens is less than one-tenth of the population in 2004. What is the first year in which this occurs? The final answer is 2009.

a_1.formal problem:
theorem
fixes N :: "nat \<Rightarrow> real"
assumes h0 : "\<forall> n \<ge> 1. N n = N (n - 1) * 0.6"
and h1 : "\<forall> n \<ge> 0. N n > 0.1 * N 0"
shows  "N 5 \<le> 0.1 * N 0" (* Less than 10% of the original number in 5 years (2009 - 2004) *)
a_1.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 Every June 1, an ecologist takes a census of the number of wrens in a state park. She noticed that the number is decreasing by $40\%$ each year. If this trend continues, in what year will the census show that the number of wrens is less than $10\%$ of what it was on June 1, 2004? The final Answer is 2009
 ### Proof
 After one year, there will be $60\%$ left. After two years, there will be $36\%$ left. After three years, there will be $21.6\%$ left. As we can see, these are just increasing powers of $60\%$, the next year will not dip below $10\%$, because $60\% > 50\%$, and $21.6 > 20$.
 However, without calculating it exactly, you know that it will be less than $16.6\%$, and thus, it will take 5 years - meaning that in $\boxed{2009}$, the total number of wrens will drop below $10\%$ of what it originally was.
 *)

theorem
fixes N :: "nat \<Rightarrow> real"
assumes h0 : "\<forall> n \<ge> 1. N n = N (n - 1) * 0.6"
and h1 : "\<forall> n \<ge> 0. N n > 0.1 * N 0"
shows  "N 5 \<le> 0.1 * N 0" (* Less than 10% of the original number in 5 years (2009 - 2004) *)
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_1.informal problem: A quantity N decreases by 40% each year. Is it true that after 5 years, N will be less than or equal to 10% of its original value?

a_2.formal problem:
theorem
fixes wrens :: "int \<Rightarrow> int"
assumes h0 : "\<forall>n. n >= 2004 \<longrightarrow> wrens n = (0.6 ^ (n - 2004)) * wrens 2004"
shows  "\<exists>n. n >= 2004 \<and> wrens n < 0.1 * wrens 2004 \<and> (\<forall>m. m > n \<longrightarrow> wrens m < 0.1 * wrens 2004)"
a_2.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 Every June 1, an ecologist takes a census of the number of wrens in a state park. She noticed that the number is decreasing by $40\%$ each year. If this trend continues, in what year will the census show that the number of wrens is less than $10\%$ of what it was on June 1, 2004? The final Answer is 2009
 ### Proof
 After one year, there will be $60\%$ left. After two years, there will be $36\%$ left. After three years, there will be $21.6\%$ left. As we can see, these are just increasing powers of $60\%$, the next year will not dip below $10\%$, because $60\% > 50\%$, and $21.6 > 20$.
 However, without calculating it exactly, you know that it will be less than $16.6\%$, and thus, it will take 5 years - meaning that in $\boxed{2009}$, the total number of wrens will drop below $10\%$ of what it originally was.
 *)

theorem
fixes wrens :: "int \<Rightarrow> int"
assumes h0 : "\<forall>n. n >= 2004 \<longrightarrow> wrens n = (0.6 ^ (n - 2004)) * wrens 2004"
shows  "\<exists>n. n >= 2004 \<and> wrens n < 0.1 * wrens 2004 \<and> (\<forall>m. m > n \<longrightarrow> wrens m < 0.1 * wrens 2004)"

 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_2.informal problem: Suppose the population of wrens in 2004 is reduced each year by a factor of 0.6. Is there a year after 2004 where the population of wrens is less than 10% of the population in 2004, and continues to be less than 10% in the following years?

a_3.formal problem:
theorem
fixes wrens :: "int \<Rightarrow> int"
and year :: int
assumes h0 : "\<forall> year. year \<ge> 2004 \<longrightarrow> wrens year = wrens (year - 1) * 0.6"
and h1 : "wrens 2004 = 100"
and h2 : "\<forall> year. year \<ge> 2004 \<longrightarrow> wrens year \<ge> 10"
shows  "year = 2009"
a_3.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 Every June 1, an ecologist takes a census of the number of wrens in a state park. She noticed that the number is decreasing by $40\%$ each year. If this trend continues, in what year will the census show that the number of wrens is less than $10\%$ of what it was on June 1, 2004? The final Answer is 2009
 ### Proof
 After one year, there will be $60\%$ left. After two years, there will be $36\%$ left. After three years, there will be $21.6\%$ left. As we can see, these are just increasing powers of $60\%$, the next year will not dip below $10\%$, because $60\% > 50\%$, and $21.6 > 20$.
 However, without calculating it exactly, you know that it will be less than $16.6\%$, and thus, it will take 5 years - meaning that in $\boxed{2009}$, the total number of wrens will drop below $10\%$ of what it originally was.
 *)

theorem
fixes wrens :: "int \<Rightarrow> int"
and year :: int
assumes h0 : "\<forall> year. year \<ge> 2004 \<longrightarrow> wrens year = wrens (year - 1) * 0.6"
and h1 : "wrens 2004 = 100"
and h2 : "\<forall> year. year \<ge> 2004 \<longrightarrow> wrens year \<ge> 10"
shows  "year = 2009"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_3.informal problem: The population of wrens in a certain area decreases by 40% each year starting from the year 2004. In 2004, the population was 100. What is the last year in which the population was still at least 10? The final answer is 2009.

a_4.formal problem:
theorem
fixes wrens :: "int \<Rightarrow> int"
assumes h0 : "\<forall>n. n \<ge> 2004 \<longrightarrow> wrens n = (0.6 ^ (n - 2004)) * wrens 2004"
and h1 : "\<forall>n. n \<ge> 2004 \<longrightarrow> wrens n \<ge> 0.1 * wrens 2004"
shows  "\<exists>n. n \<ge> 2009 \<and> wrens n < 0.1 * wrens 2004"
a_4.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 Every June 1, an ecologist takes a census of the number of wrens in a state park. She noticed that the number is decreasing by $40\%$ each year. If this trend continues, in what year will the census show that the number of wrens is less than $10\%$ of what it was on June 1, 2004? The final Answer is 2009
 ### Proof
 After one year, there will be $60\%$ left. After two years, there will be $36\%$ left. After three years, there will be $21.6\%$ left. As we can see, these are just increasing powers of $60\%$, the next year will not dip below $10\%$, because $60\% > 50\%$, and $21.6 > 20$.
 However, without calculating it exactly, you know that it will be less than $16.6\%$, and thus, it will take 5 years - meaning that in $\boxed{2009}$, the total number of wrens will drop below $10\%$ of what it originally was.
 *)

theorem
fixes wrens :: "int \<Rightarrow> int"
assumes h0 : "\<forall>n. n \<ge> 2004 \<longrightarrow> wrens n = (0.6 ^ (n - 2004)) * wrens 2004"
and h1 : "\<forall>n. n \<ge> 2004 \<longrightarrow> wrens n \<ge> 0.1 * wrens 2004"
shows  "\<exists>n. n \<ge> 2009 \<and> wrens n < 0.1 * wrens 2004"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_4.informal problem: The population of wrens in a certain area in the year 2004 is decreasing each subsequent year by a factor of 0.6. Even so, for every year since 2004, the population has always been at least 10% of the 2004 population. Is there a year after 2009 in which the population of wrens is less than 10% of the 2004 population?

a_5.formal problem:
theorem
fixes wrens_2004 wrens_future :: real
and year :: nat
assumes h0 : "wrens_2004 > 0"
and h1 : "wrens_future = wrens_2004 * (0.6 ^ year)"
and h2 : "wrens_future < 0.1 * wrens_2004"
shows  "year = 2009"
a_5.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 Every June 1, an ecologist takes a census of the number of wrens in a state park. She noticed that the number is decreasing by $40\%$ each year. If this trend continues, in what year will the census show that the number of wrens is less than $10\%$ of what it was on June 1, 2004? The final Answer is 2009
 ### Proof
 After one year, there will be $60\%$ left. After two years, there will be $36\%$ left. After three years, there will be $21.6\%$ left. As we can see, these are just increasing powers of $60\%$, the next year will not dip below $10\%$, because $60\% > 50\%$, and $21.6 > 20$.
 However, without calculating it exactly, you know that it will be less than $16.6\%$, and thus, it will take 5 years - meaning that in $\boxed{2009}$, the total number of wrens will drop below $10\%$ of what it originally was.
 *)

theorem
fixes wrens_2004 wrens_future :: real
and year :: nat
assumes h0 : "wrens_2004 > 0"
and h1 : "wrens_future = wrens_2004 * (0.6 ^ year)"
and h2 : "wrens_future < 0.1 * wrens_2004"
shows  "year = 2009"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_5.informal problem: In 2004, there were more than zero wrens. Each year, the wren population decreases to 60% of its size the previous year. In what year will the wren population be less than 10% of its size in 2004? The answer is 2009.

a_6.formal problem:
theorem
fixes wrens :: "int \<Rightarrow> int"
and year :: int
assumes h0 : "wrens 2004 = w"
and h1 : "\<forall> y. y > 2004 \<longrightarrow> wrens y = wrens (y-1) * 0.6"
shows  "\<exists> y. y > 2004 \<and> wrens y < w * 0.1"
a_6.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 Every June 1, an ecologist takes a census of the number of wrens in a state park. She noticed that the number is decreasing by $40\%$ each year. If this trend continues, in what year will the census show that the number of wrens is less than $10\%$ of what it was on June 1, 2004? The final Answer is 2009
 ### Proof
 After one year, there will be $60\%$ left. After two years, there will be $36\%$ left. After three years, there will be $21.6\%$ left. As we can see, these are just increasing powers of $60\%$, the next year will not dip below $10\%$, because $60\% > 50\%$, and $21.6 > 20$.
 However, without calculating it exactly, you know that it will be less than $16.6\%$, and thus, it will take 5 years - meaning that in $\boxed{2009}$, the total number of wrens will drop below $10\%$ of what it originally was.
 *)

theorem
fixes wrens :: "int \<Rightarrow> int"
and year :: int
assumes h0 : "wrens 2004 = w"
and h1 : "\<forall> y. y > 2004 \<longrightarrow> wrens y = wrens (y-1) * 0.6"
shows  "\<exists> y. y > 2004 \<and> wrens y < w * 0.1"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_6.informal problem: In 2004, the population of wrens was $w$. If the population decreases by 40% each year after 2004, find a year when the population of wrens is less than 10% of the population in 2004.

a_7.formal problem:
theorem
fixes wrens :: "int \<Rightarrow> int"
assumes h0 : "wrens 2004 = 100"
and h1 : "\<forall> y. y > 2004 \<longrightarrow> wrens y = (0.6) * wrens (y - 1)"
shows  "EX y. y > 2004 \<and> wrens y < 10"
a_7.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 Every June 1, an ecologist takes a census of the number of wrens in a state park. She noticed that the number is decreasing by $40\%$ each year. If this trend continues, in what year will the census show that the number of wrens is less than $10\%$ of what it was on June 1, 2004? The final Answer is 2009
 ### Proof
 After one year, there will be $60\%$ left. After two years, there will be $36\%$ left. After three years, there will be $21.6\%$ left. As we can see, these are just increasing powers of $60\%$, the next year will not dip below $10\%$, because $60\% > 50\%$, and $21.6 > 20$.
 However, without calculating it exactly, you know that it will be less than $16.6\%$, and thus, it will take 5 years - meaning that in $\boxed{2009}$, the total number of wrens will drop below $10\%$ of what it originally was.
 *)

theorem
fixes wrens :: "int \<Rightarrow> int"
assumes h0 : "wrens 2004 = 100"
and h1 : "\<forall> y. y > 2004 \<longrightarrow> wrens y = (0.6) * wrens (y - 1)"
shows  "EX y. y > 2004 \<and> wrens y < 10"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_7.informal problem: "In 2004, there were 100 wrens. Each year after 2004, the number of wrens decreases to 60% of the previous year's population. Is there a year after 2004 where the number of wrens is less than 10?"

a_8.formal problem:
theorem
fixes wrens :: "int \<Rightarrow> real"
assumes h0 : "wrens 2004 > 0"
and h1 : "\<forall> y. y > 2004 \<longrightarrow> wrens y = wrens (y - 1) * 0.6"
shows  "\<exists> y. y >= 2004 \<and> wrens y < wrens 2004 * 0.1 \<and> (ALL z. z > y \<longrightarrow> wrens z >= wrens y)"
a_8.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 Every June 1, an ecologist takes a census of the number of wrens in a state park. She noticed that the number is decreasing by $40\%$ each year. If this trend continues, in what year will the census show that the number of wrens is less than $10\%$ of what it was on June 1, 2004? The final Answer is 2009
 ### Proof
 After one year, there will be $60\%$ left. After two years, there will be $36\%$ left. After three years, there will be $21.6\%$ left. As we can see, these are just increasing powers of $60\%$, the next year will not dip below $10\%$, because $60\% > 50\%$, and $21.6 > 20$.
 However, without calculating it exactly, you know that it will be less than $16.6\%$, and thus, it will take 5 years - meaning that in $\boxed{2009}$, the total number of wrens will drop below $10\%$ of what it originally was.
 *)

theorem
fixes wrens :: "int \<Rightarrow> real"
assumes h0 : "wrens 2004 > 0"
and h1 : "\<forall> y. y > 2004 \<longrightarrow> wrens y = wrens (y - 1) * 0.6"
shows  "\<exists> y. y >= 2004 \<and> wrens y < wrens 2004 * 0.1 \<and> (ALL z. z > y \<longrightarrow> wrens z >= wrens y)"

 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_8.informal problem: In 2004, there was a positive number of wrens (a type of bird). Each year after 2004, the wren population decreased to 60% of the previous year's population. Is there a year after 2004 in which the wren population is less than 10% of the 2004 population and from which the population never increases?

a_9.formal problem:
function wren_census :: "nat \<Rightarrow> real"
where
"wren_census 2004 = initial"
| "n > 2004 \<Longrightarrow> wren_census n = wren_census (n-1) * 0.6"
by pat_completeness auto
termination by (relation "measure (\<lambda>n. n - 2004)") auto

theorem wren_census_less_than_10_percent:
assumes h0 : "initial > 0"
and h1 : "wren_census 2004 = initial"
shows  "\<exists>n. n > 2004 \<and> wren_census n < initial * 0.1 \<and> (\<forall>m. m > 2004 \<and> m < n \<longrightarrow> wren_census m \<ge> initial * 0.1)"
a_9.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 Every June 1, an ecologist takes a census of the number of wrens in a state park. She noticed that the number is decreasing by $40\%$ each year. If this trend continues, in what year will the census show that the number of wrens is less than $10\%$ of what it was on June 1, 2004? The final Answer is 2009
 ### Proof
 After one year, there will be $60\%$ left. After two years, there will be $36\%$ left. After three years, there will be $21.6\%$ left. As we can see, these are just increasing powers of $60\%$, the next year will not dip below $10\%$, because $60\% > 50\%$, and $21.6 > 20$.
 However, without calculating it exactly, you know that it will be less than $16.6\%$, and thus, it will take 5 years - meaning that in $\boxed{2009}$, the total number of wrens will drop below $10\%$ of what it originally was.
 *)



function wren_census :: "nat \<Rightarrow> real"
where
"wren_census 2004 = initial"
| "n > 2004 \<Longrightarrow> wren_census n = wren_census (n-1) * 0.6"
by pat_completeness auto
termination by (relation "measure (\<lambda>n. n - 2004)") auto

theorem wren_census_less_than_10_percent:
assumes h0 : "initial > 0"
and h1 : "wren_census 2004 = initial"
shows  "\<exists>n. n > 2004 \<and> wren_census n < initial * 0.1 \<and> (\<forall>m. m > 2004 \<and> m < n \<longrightarrow> wren_census m \<ge> initial * 0.1)"

 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_9.informal problem: If the initial population of wrens in 2004 is positive, and each subsequent year the population decreases to 60% of the previous year's population, find the first year after 2004 when the population of wrens will be less than 10% of the initial population. Ensure that in all preceding years, the population of wrens never fell below 10% of the initial population.
